Authors:
Margarita Villegas-Rios, Rodolfo Salas-Lizana, Roberto
Garibay-Orijel, Julieta Alvarez-Manjarrez
Title:
New Mesoamerican lineages of Clavulina from Mexico reveal a
biogeographic link between tropical and temperate regions
Keywords:
Clavulinaceae phylogeny, ITS, RPB2, biogeography, 3 new
taxa
Abstract:
Clavulina comprises ca. 82 described species, distributed
in both tropical and temperate regions. Clavulina belongs to
Clavulinaceae, along with Membranomyces, the Sistotrema
brinkmanni-oblongisporum group and Multiclavula. However, the
phylogenetic relationships within the family and this genus are not
completely resolved. It has been proposed that Clavulina has a tropical
origin with a derived group of species (i.e. the C. cristata group) with
temperate distribution. To test this hypothesis, we sampled mycorrhizae
and basidiocarps of Clavulina in three tropical biogeographic provinces
of Mexico. We used morphological data and two molecular markers, the nuc
rDNA Internal Transcribed Spacer (ITS) region and a fragment of the RNA
polymerase II gene (RPB2), to differentiate new species and infer their
phylogeny. However, RPB2 phylogeny was inconsistent with both
morphological and ITS data. The ITS phylogeny was also used to
reconstruct ancestral habitats (i.e. temperate or tropical) and estimate
net diversification rates. Nine new lineages were discovered, from which
three new species are proposed (C. arboreoparva, C. subtilis and C.
tuxtlasana). The ITS phylogeny places all the new lineages as basal on
the C. cristata group, confirming a tropical origin for Clavulina and,
contrary to previous hypotheses, it suggests a tropical ancestor for the
entire C. cristata group. Additionally, a lineage including only
Holarctic species with a temperate ancestor is proposed. We suggest that
Mesoamerica is a link between tropical species in South America and the
northern hemisphere. The new described species share some morphological
characters with temperate Clavulina, such as simple or branched
basidiomata and whitish-grey hymenium. KEY WORDS Clavulinaceae
phylogeny, ITS, RPB2, biogeography, 3 new taxa
